body.p:
To His Exellency
Jas F. Robinson
Govenor of Kentucky

Your Petitioner Jas. C. Bradley would respectfully state, that he was arrested on the 10th inst charged with stealing a pistol, & was indicted in the Jefferson Circuit & tried on the 24th inst, & found guilty by a Jury for one year, the lowest Term fixed by our statute.

The circumstances of the taking are as followes, Petitioner being threatened by a man greatly his superior in strength, & fearing that great bodily harm would be done him took from the possession of prosecuting witness the pistol charged to have been stolen; the pistol was detained between two & three hours, when he was found with it upon him: He was immediately arrested & swiftly tried, & convicted to in the Penitentiary house of this commonwealth for one long year. One year to those pursuing hapy pursuits, will swiftly pass away, but to inhabit that dreadful house for one year it seems interminable.

Your petitioner has a bodily infirmity, which has caused him untold suffering, one leg by disease has become much shorter than its mate
& he hobbles as he walks.

Your petitioner does not stand alone in the world, he has a wife & children, & for these dear ones, more than him self, he asks your Excellency to keep him out of that terrible house. Your petitioner is advanced in years the spring, summer, & autumn of his life has passed in happiness & peace, but now in the winter of his life those peaceful -- hapy scenes have changed, & mortifications & despair have come in their stead: I am not guilty, but unfortunate I could not be made a fellon. I hope your Excellency will pity my condition, & grant me a pardon

With great respect
I subscribe myself
Your hopeful servant
James C Bradley
No good ground for Exctv interpose Pettn Exd & refusd
Mr. Thomas jailor of Louisville gives statement unparalleled
